data.text: After these things Jesus continued to move about in Galilee,All of chapter six took place in Galilee, so why make a point of Jesus' continuing there? 6:4 says that the Passover was near, but 7:2 says that the Feast of Tabernacles was near‚Äîthat is six months later. As a God-fearing male, Jesus had to go to Jerusalem for the Passover, so He must have gone, although none of the Gospels records it. I take it that He went without calling attention to Himself, and returned immediately to Galilee, for the reason given in the second half of the verse. since He did not wish to move about in Judea because the Jews were wanting to kill Him.Between 6:71 and 7:2 six months elapsed. For events that occurred during that period see Matthew 15:1-18:35, Mark 7:1-9:50 and Luke 9:18-50.
Now the Jews' Feast of Tabernacles was near.

So His brothers said to Him: ‚ÄúLeave here and go up into Judea so your disciples alsoThese would have to be dwellers in Judea who were not following Jesus around. Since His statement about eating His flesh, the number of hangers-on was drastically reduced, giving the impression that He was losing popularity in Galilee. may see the works that you are doing,
because no one does anything in secret while he actually wants to be in evidence. Since you are doing these things, show yourself to the world!‚Äù

For not even His brothers were believing into Him.Well now, those brothers were not very nice, were they? I take it that they knew very well that the hierarchy was plotting to kill Jesus (it seems to me obvious that the Jews had researched Jesus' past and family, and had doubtless been working on His brothers), so they were trying to send Him to His death. With friends like that, who needs enemies?
So Jesus says to them: ‚ÄúMy time is not here yet, but your time is always available.I assume that He meant that they could repent and believe into Him at any time.

The world cannot hate you, but does hate me, because I testify about it that its works are malignant.If we raise the standard of biblical values in the public arena, calling a spade a spade, the world will hate us too‚Äîtry it and see!

You guys go up to this feast; I am not going up yetPerhaps 3% of the Greek manuscripts, of inferior quality, omit ‚Äúyet‚Äù (as in NASB, TEV, RSV, etc.). The reading of the so-called ‚Äòcritical‚Äô text has the effect of ascribing a falsehood to Jesus, since He did in fact go to the feast (and doubtless knew what He was going to do). Among the 97% are ùïª66,75 and B‚Äîsince the UBS editors usually attach the highest value to ùïª75 and B, isn't it strange that they reject them in this case? to this feast, because my time has not yet fully come.‚Äù
So upon saying these things to them He stayed on in Galilee.That is, His brothers started out on their way to Jerusalem and Jesus stayed behind, for the moment.
Now when His brothers had gone up to the feast, then He too went up, not openly but in secret like.
So the Jews were looking for Him at the feast and saying, ‚ÄúWhere is he?‚Äù
And there was a lot of murmuring about Him among the crowds. Some were saying, ‚ÄúHe is good‚Äù; others were saying, ‚ÄúOn the contrary, he's deceiving the people.‚Äù
However, no one was talking openly about Him for fear of the Jews.
Now when the feast was already half over Jesus went up into the temple and started to teach.

And the Jews were marveling saying, ‚ÄúHow is this man learned, not having been educated?‚ÄùThat is, He had never been to a recognized theological seminary, rabbinical school, or whatever. But He knew more than they did! (Which of course was hard for them to swallow.)
So Jesus answered them and said: ‚ÄúWhat I teach is not mine, but His who sent me.Jesus is evidently aware of what they are saying or thinking, since He addresses it.

If anyone wants to do His will,If we want to do, we will know. The Lord did not say, if we just want to know‚Äîwe have to be committed to obey before we know what the order is. Once we are committed to obey, it is in God's own interest to talk to us. he will know concerning the teaching, whether it is from God or whether I am speaking on my own.
Someone who speaks on his own is seeking his own glory; but He who seeks the glory of the One who sent Him, He is true, and there is no unrighteousness in Him.
‚ÄúDid not Moses give you the Law? And yet not one of you keeps the Law! Why do you want to kill me?‚Äù

The crowd answered and said, ‚ÄúYou must have a demon! Who wants to kill you?‚ÄùThe ‚Äòcrowd‚Äô is made up of common people who are not in the know with a sprinkling of Pharisee types, the bosses. Jesus is really addressing the bosses, but the common people don't get it.
Jesus answered and said to them: ‚ÄúI did one work, and you all marvel.
Consider this: Moses gave you circumcision (not that it comes from Moses, but from the patriarchs),It started with Abraham, 430 years before Moses. and you circumcise a man on the Sabbath.

If a man receives circumcision on the Sabbath, so that the Law of Moses won't be broken, are you angry at me because I made a whole manThe Lord seems to be contrasting circumcision, which involves only a small part of the body, with His healing, which involved the whole body. well on the Sabbath?Hey, the last healing on a Sabbath in Jerusalem, as recorded by John, happened a year and a half ago! In fact, none of the four Gospels records any activity by Jesus in Jerusalem during the year and a half since John 5. Jesus seems to be implying that they are still mad about that!
Stop judging on the basis of appearances, but judge the righteous judgment.‚Äù
Now some of the Jerusalemites were saying: ‚ÄúIsn't this the man they are wanting to kill?
Yet look! He is speaking openly and they are saying nothing to Him. Could it be true that the rulers know that this is really the Christ?

On the other hand, we know where this man is from; but whenever the Christ comes nobody knows where He is from.‚ÄùIf no one could know where the Messiah came from, how come the rulers were able to tell Herod that the Messiah would be born in Bethlehem? The people had bought into a false idea. Verses 25-27 presumably record bits from various speakers.
So Jesus called out in the temple, teaching and saying: ‚ÄúYou do know me, and you know where I am from. Yet I have not come on my own, but the One who sent me is true, whom you do not know.

I do know Him because I am from Him, and He sent me.‚ÄùThe Lord is very emphatic about His heavenly origin. Of course the Jews want to be rid of Him because He most definitely is not fitting into their scheme of things. I take it that there is divine intervention at work so they are not able to arrest Him.
So they tried to arrest Him, yet no one laid a hand on Him because His hour had not yet come.
Now many of the crowd were believing into Him, and they were saying, ‚ÄúWhenever the Christ comes He won't perform more signs than these which this man has done, will He?‚Äù
The Pharisees heard the crowd murmuring these things about Him, so the Pharisees and the chief priests sent operatives to arrest Him.
Then Jesus said: ‚ÄúFor a little while I am still with you, and then I go to the One who sent me.

You will look for me and not find me; also, where I am you cannot come.‚Äù‚ÄúWhere I am‚Äù‚Äîthat is what the Text says. I imagine that the idea is the same as in John 3:13, ‚Äúwho is in Heaven‚Äù. He has just said in verse 33 that He is going back to Heaven. So, He is telling those Jewish leaders that they cannot go to Heaven!
So the Jews said among themselves: ‚ÄúWhere does this fellow intend to go that we won't find him? He doesn't intend to go to the Dispersion among the Greeks and teach the Greeks, does he?
What word is this that he spoke, ‚ÄòYou will look for me and not find me‚Äô; also, ‚Äòwhere I am you cannot come‚Äô?‚Äù
Now on the last and most important day of the Feast, Jesus stood up and called out saying: ‚ÄúIf anyone thirsts, let him come to me and drink.

The one believing into me, just as the Scripture has said, out from his innermost being will flow rivers of living water.‚ÄùJust where does the Scripture say this, and why ‚Äúrivers‚Äù (pl); wouldn't one be enough? Reference Bibles will give a variety of suggestions, none of which really fit. I personally believe that the reference is to Ezekiel 47:1-12, and most especially to verse 9 where the Hebrew text has two rivers (or torrents)‚Äîwhen that river got to the Dead Sea it evidently divided, so as to go along both banks at once. Living water takes life and health wherever it goes. So how much living water is flowing out of me, or you? The secret of that water is given in verse 12: ‚Äútheir water flows from the sanctuary‚Äù (compare 1 Corinthians 6:19).

(Now He said this about the Spirit, whom those believing into Him were going to receive,When you believe into Jesus you receive the Holy Spirit. in that the Holy Spirit had not yet been given because Jesus had not yet been glorified.)
So upon hearing this word many from the crowd began to say, ‚ÄúThis One really is ‚Äòthe Prophet‚Äô!‚Äù
Others were saying, ‚ÄúThis One is the Christ!‚Äù Others were saying: ‚ÄúSurely the Christ isn't coming out of Galilee, is He?

Doesn't the Scripture say that the Christ comes out of the seed of David and from the town of Bethlehem, where David was?‚ÄùI smell a rat. In verse 27 above they claimed that no one knew where the Christ was coming from; now here they say it is Beth-lehem. I suspect that there were people planted in the crowd whose job it was to create confusion, and they felt no obligation to tell the truth.
So there developed a division in the crowd because of Him.
Further, some of them were wanting to arrest Him, but no one laid a hand on Him.
Then the operatives came to the chief priests and Pharisees, who said to them, ‚ÄúWhy haven't you brought him?‚Äù
The operatives answered, ‚ÄúNo man ever spoke like this man!‚Äù
So the Pharisees answered them: ‚ÄúYou haven't been fooled too, have you?
None of the rulers or the Pharisees have believed into him, have they?
But this crowd that doesn't know the law is accursed!‚Äù
Nicodemus (the one who came to Him at night, being one of them) says to them,
‚ÄúOur law doesn't judge a man before it hears him and knows what he is doing, does it?‚Äù

They answered and said to him: ‚ÄúYou aren't from Galilee too, are you? Search and see that no prophet has ever arisen out of Galilee.‚ÄùA bit of an overstatement‚ÄîJonah was from Gath Hepher of Zebulun, north of Natsareth (2 Kings 14:25).

So each one went to his own house.Some 15% of the Greek manuscripts omit 7:53-8:11, including most of the early ones; but that means that 85% contain it, including the Latin tradition that dates from the 2nd century. Assuming (for the sake of the argument) that the passage is spurious, how could it ever have intruded here, and to such effect that it is attested by some 85% of the MSS? Let's try to read the larger passage without these verses‚Äîwe must go from 7:52 to 8:12 directly. Reviewing the context, the chief priests and Pharisees had sent officers to arrest Jesus, to no avail; a ‚Äòdiscussion‚Äô ensues; Nicodemus makes a point, to which the Pharisees answer: (7:52) ‚ÄúAre you also from Galilee? Search and look, for no prophet has arisen out of Galilee.‚Äù (8:12) Then Jesus spoke to them again, saying, ‚ÄúI am the light of the world‚Ä¶‚Äù What is the antecedent of ‚Äúthem‚Äù, and what is the meaning of ‚Äúagain‚Äù? By the normal rules of grammar, if 7:53‚Äî8:11 is missing then ‚Äúthem‚Äù must refer to the ‚ÄúPharisees‚Äù and ‚Äúagain‚Äù means that there has already been at least one prior exchange. But, 7:45 makes clear that Jesus was not there with the Pharisees. Thus, UBS [the ‚Äòcritical‚Äô text] introduces an aberration. And yet, Metzger claims that the passage ‚Äúinterrupts the sequence of 7.52 and 8.12 ff.‚Äù (p. 220)! To look for the antecedents of 8:12 in 7:37-39 not only does despite to the syntax but also runs afoul of 8:13‚Äî‚Äúthe Pharisees‚Äù respond to Jesus' claim in verse 12, but ‚Äúthe Pharisees‚Äù are somewhere else, 7:45-52 (if the Pericope is absent). Metzger also claims that ‚Äúthe style and vocabulary of the pericope differ noticeably from the rest of the Fourth Gospel‚Äù‚Äîbut, would not the native speakers of Greek at that time have been in a better position than modern critics to notice something like that? So how could they allow such an ‚Äúextraneous‚Äù passage to be forced into the text? I submit that the evident answer is that they did not; it was there all the time. I also protest their use of brackets here. Since the editors clearly regard the passage to be spurious they should be consistent and delete it, as do NEB and Williams. That way the full extent of their error would be open for all to see. Unfortunately, NIV, NASB, NRSV, Berkeley and TEV also use brackets to question the legitimacy of this passage. But why was the story omitted? Leading church father and theologian, Augustine (about ad 430), answers: ‚ÄúCertain persons of little faith, or rather enemies of the true faith, fearing, I suppose, lest their wives should be given impunity in sinning, removed from their manuscripts the Lord's acts of forgiveness toward the adulteress, as if He who said ‚Äòsin no more‚Äô had granted permission to sin.‚Äù (See Augustine, ‚ÄúAdulterous Marriages‚Äù [2.7] trans. by Charles T. Huegelmeyer, in Saint Augustine: Treatises on Marriage and Other Subjects [New York: Fathers of the Church, 1955], p. 107.) [I took this material on Augustine from Living Water: The Gospel of John‚ÄîLogos 21 Version, Absolutely Free Incorporated, p. 74.]
